recognized as continuing in force by reference thereto the chapters of the arranged in alphabetical order and the sections within each chapter are catchlined to facilitate usage footnotes which tie related sections of the which refer to relevant provisions of the state law have been included a table listing the state law citations setting forth their location within the included at the back of this volume the source of each section is indicated by the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof the absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the use of the comparative table also appearing in the back of the volume any ordinance included herein can be readily found in the system the numbering system used in this the same system used in many state and municipal codes each section number consists of two component parts separated by a dash the figure before the dash representing the chapter number and the figure after the dash indicating the position of the section within the chapter thus the first section of is numbered 11 and the fifteenth section of is 915 under this system each section is identified with its chapter and at the same time new sections or even whole chapters can be inserted in their proper places simply by using the decimal system for amendments by way of illustration if new material consisting of three sections that would logically come between sections 45 and 46 is desired to be added such new sections would be numbered 451 452 453 respectively new chapters may be included in the same manner if the new material is to be included between chapters 12 and 13 it will be designated as care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters new articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or in the case of articles may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject and in the case of divisions may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject the next successive number being assigned to the article or division page numbering system the page numbering system used in this a prefix system the letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume the number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion in the case of a chapter of the the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the chapter in the case of an appendix to the the letter immediately to the left of the colon indicates the letter of the appendix the following are typical parts of codes of ordinances which may or may not appear in this this time and their corresponding prefixes code cd code appendix cda1 code comparative tables cct1 state law reference table slt1 code index cdi1 index the index has been prepared with the greatest of care each particular item has been placed under several headings some of the headings being couched in lay phraseology others in legal terminology and still others in language generally used by municipal officials and employees there are numerous cross references within the index itself which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which he is interested looseleaf supplements a special feature of this the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental service by which the be kept uptodate periodically upon the final passage of amendatory ordinances they will be properly edited and the page or pages affected will be reprinted these new pages will be distributed to the holders of the instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages each such amendment when incorporated into the may be cited as a part thereof as provided in section 5 of the adopting successful maintenance of this todate at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the volume as revised sheets are received it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions it is strongly recommended by the publishers that all such amendments be inserted it ordained by the city council of the city of south houston texas the ordinances consisting of chapters 1 to 24 each inclusive is hereby adopted and enacted as the ordinances city of south houston texas and such be treated and considered as a new and original comprehensive ordinance which shall supersede all other general and permanent ordinances passed by the city council on or before  to the extent provided in section 2 hereof all provisions of such be in full force and effect from and after the 1st day of august 197 and all ordinances of a general and permanent nature enacted on final passage on or before  and not included in such recognized and continued in force by reference thereto are hereby repealed from and after the 1st day of august 1978 the repeal provided for in section 2 hereof shall not be construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a subsequent ordinance which is repealed by this ordinance whenever in such act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor or whenever in such doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful and no specific penalty is provided therefor the violation of any such provision of such be punished by a fine not exceeding two hundred dollars $20000 as provided in section 17 of such  any and all additions and amendments to such when passed in such form as to indicate the intention of the city council to make the same a part thereof shall be deemed to be incorporated in such that reference to the ordinances city of south houston texas shall be understood and intended to include such additions and amendments in case of the amendment of any section of such which a penalty is not provided the general penalty as provided in section 4 of this ordinance and section 17 of such apply to the section as amended  or in case such amendment contains provisions for which a penalty other than the aforementioned general penalty is provided in another section in the same chapter the penalty so provided in such other section shall be held to relate to the section so amended unless such penalty is specifically repealed therein a copy of such be kept on file in the office of the city secretary preserved in looseleaf form or in such other form as the city secretary may consider most expendient it shall be the express duty of the city secretary or someone authorized by him to insert in their designated places all amendments or ordinances which indicate the intention of the city council to make the same a part of such the same have been printed or reprinted in page form and to extract from such provisions which may be from time to time repealed by the city council this copy of such be available for all persons desiring to examine the same it shall be unlawful for any person to change or amend by additions or deletions any part or portion of such or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof or to alter or tamper with such any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the city of south houston to be misrepresented thereby any person violating this section shall be punished as provided in section 4 of this ordinance all ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are to the extent of such conflict hereby repealed this ordinance shall become effective on the 1st day of august 1978 passed and councilman the word alderman or councilman shall mean a duly elected member of the city council of the city of south houston city the term the city this city or city shall mean the city of south houston in the county of harris and state of texas words this  shall mean the ordinances city of south houston texas as designated in section 11 computation of time whenever a notice is required to be given or an act to be done a certain length of time before any proceeding shall be had the day on which such notice is given or such act is done shall be counted in computing the time but the day on which such proceeding is to be had shall not be counted council this council the council city council whenever the term council this council the council or city council is used it shall mean the city council of the city of south houston texas county the term county the county or this county shall mean harris county texas gender a word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms partnerships and corporations as well as to males highway the term highway shall include any street alley highway avenue or public place or square bridge viaduct tunnel underpass overpass and causeway in the city dedicated or devoted to public use joint authority words purporting to give authority to three 3 or more officers or other persons shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such officers or other persons unless it is otherwise declared month the word month shall mean a calendar month number any word importing the singular number shall include the plural and any word importing the plural number shall include the singular oath the word oath shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which by law an affirmation may be substituted for an oath and in such cases the words swear and sworn shall be equivalent to the words affirm and affirmed officers boards etc whenever reference is made to any officer board commission or other agency the same shall be construed as if followed by the words of the city of south houston reference to any specific officer shall also be deemed to include his duly authorized assistants and representatives or and or may be read and and and may be read or if the sense requires it owner the word owner applied to a building or land shall include any part owner joint owner tenant in common tenant in partnership joint tenant or tenant by the entirety of the whole or of a part of such building or land person the word person shall extend and be applied to associations corporations firms partnerships and bodies politic and corporate as well as to individuals roadway the word roadway shall mean that portion of a street improved designed or ordinarily used for vehicular traffic sidewalk the word sidewalk shall mean any portion of the street between the curb or the lateral line of the roadway and the adjacent property line intended for the use of pedestrians signature or subscription the word signature or subscription shall include a mark when a person cannot write state the word the state or this state shall be construed to mean the state of texas street the term street shall include any highway alley street avenue or public place or square bridge viaduct underpass overpass tunnel or causeway in the city dedicated or devoted to public use tense words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present written or in writing the term written or in writing shall be construed to include any representation of words letters or figures whether by printing or otherwise year the word year shall mean a calendar year state law reference similar definitions vtca government  catchlines of sections the catchlines of the thousand dollars $200000  all other violation of this code or any ordinance of the city in which an act is prohibited or made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor or whenever in appointment of municipal officers department heads and volunteers a appointments generally this section is enacted in order to clarify who is the appointing officer with authority to appoint officers in various departments of the city administration who are not elective and any new officers created by city council it is hereby declared that the mayor shall appoint all nonelective officers heads of departments employees and such other persons as prescribed in city ordinances and the statutes of the state of texas  subject to approval of a majority of city council b officers and department heads 1 officers the city engineer chief of police municipal judge relief municipal judge city prosecutor city secretary tax assessor and collector city attorney health officer medical director plumbing electrical and building inspectors director of finance and treasurer are offices of the city whose positions are to be filled by the mayor upon the mayors appointment subject to confirmation by the majority of council nothing in this section shall preclude the appointment of an employee of the city to any one or more of the foregoing positions no employee of the city shall be required to assume appointive office the mayor has the authority to appoint any firm corporation partnership sole proprietorship or any other entity recognized by law to provide the services of the position on a contract basis subject to confirmation by the majority of council of the appointment and of the contract terms the office andor position of assistant code enforcement officer is hereby abolished the office andor position of chief financial officer is hereby abolished 2 department heads the positions of superintendent of repair and maintenance supervisor of street and bridge and supervisor of sanitation superintendent of sewer and water systems superintendent of parks and playgrounds and director of the community center are heads of their various departments the department head positions are to be filled by the mayor after approval by the majority of the city council nothing in this section shall preclude the appointment of an employee of the city to any one or more of the foregoing positions no employee of the city shall be required to assume such position c filling of vacancies 1 in the event the mayor shall appoint persons to fill any appointive position of office who does not have the approval of the majority of the city council at the first regular council meeting following the election of the mayor then the city council shall fill such appointive position or office on or before the third regular council meeting after the election of the mayor by a vote of a majority 2 if a vacancy occurs in an appointive position or office at any time other than as set out in c1 above the mayor shall make such appointment not later than the second regular meeting of the city council after the vacancy occurs if the mayor fails or refuses to do so the city council shall make such appointment on or before the next regular meeting of the city council after that meeting in which the mayor fails or refuses to act by a majority vote thereof all appointments are subject to the approval of a majority of city council if after six 6 months from the date of the vacancy the mayor has failed to name a person acceptable to a majority of council mayor may be deemed by a twothird  23  majority of council to have failed or refused to fill the vacancy if the mayor is deemed to have failed or refused to fill the vacancy the city council by majority vote shall make such appointment on or before the next regular meeting of the city council at which a quorum was present and voting after that meeting in which the mayor was deemed to have failed or refused to act or after the action determining failure or refusal to act becomes final whichever is applicable d positions of special trust and confidence the following positions of special trust and confidence appointed as prescribed by ordinance shall be afforded the status of department head relative to budgeting leadership and responsibility to the mayor or city council they shall not receive pay and are classed as volunteers 1 fire chief  2 fire marshal  3 director of emergency medical service e positions appointed by police civil service commission the following position as prescribed in the local government serving at the pleasure of the south houston police civil service commission shall be afforded the status of department head relative to budgeting the pay and allowances of this position are as prescribed by the city council 1 director of police civil service  51766   6369   9688  992  1 9192   52698   11601   7505   81605   112106     editors note  adopted  did not specifically amend the ordinance abolished medical services department created a establishment of emergency medical services department there is hereby established a city emergency medical services department for the purpose of rendering emergency onscene care medical rescue services as required and providing for transporting of acutely sick or injured persons from within the city to the nearest available emergency care facility such service will be maintained and as a volunteer service department of the city of south houston b definition of emergency emergency as it is applicable to the emergency medical service shall be construed to mean a sudden unexpected happening  an unforseen occurrence or condition  perplexing contingency or complication of circumstances  a sudden or unexpected occasion for exigency  urgency and pressing necessity an emergency is an unforseen combination of circumstances that calls for immediate action  92088 bad checks  dishonored instruments a used to pay city indebtedness if any party attempts to pay any bill charge fee tax fine or other indebtedness or obligation to the city by check money order or similar instrument and if the instrument is dishonored then 1 the bill charge fee tax fine or other indebtedness or obligation shall be deemed to remain unpaid  and 2 an additional fee of thirtyfive dollars $3500 dishonored instrument fee shall be payable to the city by the maker of any such instrument that is dishonored upon presentment such fee shall be in addition to the total amount of such bill charge fee tax fine or other indebtedness or obligation and applicable late fees for which the instrument was tendered if the city refers such instrument to a collection agency or an attorney for collection the fee for such dishonored instrument shall instead of thirtyfive dollars $3500 be the amount charged to the city by the collection agency or attorney or forty dollars $4000 whichever is less the city shall not accept checks from any person firm or corporation that has tendered any dishonored instruments in any twelvemonth period b exception to this policy this section does not apply in the case of checks money orders or similar instruments dishonored in the course of any attempt to pay any bill charge fee tax fine or other indebtedness or obligation by a check money order or similar instrument drawn on or issued by a financial institution which has had its funds frozen by involuntary or voluntary action if such freezing occurs after the attempt to pay the bill charge fee tax fine or other indebtedness or obligation in such manner in such event the party attempting such payment shall not be charged the dishonored instrument fee if the bill charge fee tax fine or other indebtedness or obligation is paid within ten 10 days from the date such party has been mailed a written notice that payment on the check money order or similar instrument has not been honored  2 2795   6501   82614 finance department financial procedures and internal controls a the city council finds it necessary for the adoption of formal written procedures to be utilized by the city finance department and departments of the city making financial transactions whether financial procedures city council  7897   72297 editors note exhibit a referred to above has not been included herein but can be found on file with the city city drug and alcohol testing policy the following is the drug and alcohol testing policy for employees and certain volunteers of the city of south houston 1 drugalcohol testing generally the city shall conduct testing in accordance with federal regulations of commercial motor vehicle operators for use of alcohol or a controlled substance that violates law or federal regulation the city shall also conduct random testing of all other city employees and conduct reasonable suspicion testing if it is believed that an employee has violated the citys prohibition against use of alcohol or controlled substances 2 applicability a these testing requirements apply to every fulltime or parttime city employee fire department volunteers and emergency medical service volunteers b all city employees are subject to random testing and reasonable suspicion testing if it is believed that an employee has violated the citys policy concerning prohibition against the use of alcohol or controlled substances 3 testing procedures the city shall ensure that all alcohol or controlled substances testing conducted under this policy complies with the procedures set forth in 49 cfr 4 notification all city employees shall receive a copy of the city policy and administrative guidelines for controlled substance and alcohol testing each such employee shall sign an acknowledgment form indicating that prior notification material has been received and understood 5 employee consent to alcohol or controlled substance testing a prior to administration of an alcohol or controlled substance test affected applicants and employees will be asked to sign a city consent form authorizing the test and permitting the release of test results to city officials the consent form shall provide a space for individuals to acknowledge that they have been notified of the citys alcohol and controlled substance policy b refusal to grant consent may result in nonemployment reassignment or termination of employment 6 tests required required testing includes preemployment postaccident random reasonable suspicion followup and returntoduty testing no employee shall refuse to submit to a postaccident alcohol or controlled substances test a random alcohol or controlled substances test a reasonable suspicion alcohol or controlled substances test or a followup alcohol or controlled substances test an employee who refuses to submit to alcohol or controlled substance reasonable suspicion test shall be deemed to have violated city policy and may be subject to disciplinary action up to and including termination 7 preemployment as a condition of employment a job applicant with the city shall receive a verified negative test result from a medical review officer for alcohol and controlled substances 8 postaccident as soon as practicable following an accident involving bodily injury a commercial motor vehicle a cityowned motor vehicle or cityowned equipment the city shall test each employee a who was performing safetysensitive functions with respect to the vehicle if the accident involved the loss of human life property damage bodily injuries  andor b who receives a citation under state or local law for a moving traffic violation arising from the accident an employee who is subject to postaccident testing shall remain readily available for such testing or may be deemed by the city to have refused to submit to testing however this provision shall not be construed to require the delay of necessary medical attention for injured people following an accident or to prohibit an employee from leaving the scene of an accident for the period necessary to obtain assistance in responding to the accident or to obtain necessary emergency medical care the city shall provide employees with necessary postaccident information procedures and instructions prior to the employees operating a cityowned motor vehicle of cityowned equipment so that employees will be able to comply with these requirements postaccident testing is the primary responsibility of the employee the results of a breath or blood test for the use of alcohol or a urine test for the use of controlled substances conducted by federal state or local officials having independent authority for the test shall be considered to meet the requirements of this section provided such tests conform to applicable federal state or local requirements and that the results of the tests are obtained by the city 9 random testing the city shall randomly select a sufficient number of employees for controlled substance and alcohol testing during each calendar year the percentage rates for alcohol and controlled substances may vary from year to year as determined by the mandate of the omnibus transportation employees testing act of 1991 the selection of employees for random alcohol and controlled substances testing shall be made by a scientifically valid method such as a random number table or a computerbased random number generator that is matched with employees social security numbers payroll identification numbers or other comparable identifying numbers under the selection process used each employee shall have an equal chance of being tested each time selections are made the city shall ensure that random alcohol and controlled substances tests conducted under this policy are unannounced and that the dates for administering random alcohol and controlled substances tests are spread reasonably throughout the calendar year each employee who is notified of selection for random alcohol andor controlled substances testing shall proceed to the test site immediately  provided however that if the employee is performing a safetysensitive function at the time of notification the city shall instead ensure that the employee ceases to perform the safetysensitive function and proceeds to the testing site as soon as possible an employee shall be tested for alcohol only while the employee is performing job functions just before the employee is to perform job functions or just after the employee has ceased performing such functions 10 reasonable suspicion alcohol the city shall require an employee to submit to an alcohol test when there is reasonable suspicion to believe that the employee has violated the citys policy regarding alcohol the citys determination that reasonable suspicion exists to require the employee to undergo an alcohol test must be based on specific contemporaneous articulable observations concerning the appearance behavior speech or body odors of the employee for cdl drivers reasonable suspicion alcohol testing may occur only if the required observations are made during just preceding or just after the period of the workday that the employee is required to be in compliance with this policy and the employee is performing job functions is about to perform job functions or has just ceased performing such functions all city employees shall be required to submit to an alcohol test when there is reasonable suspicion to believe that the employee has used or is using alcohol prior to reporting for duty or while on duty or prior to or while attending any city function on or off city property 11 reasonable suspicion controlled substances the city shall require an employee to submit to a controlled substances test when there is reasonable suspicion to believe that the employee has violated the prohibitions of this policy concerning controlled substances the citys determination that reasonable suspicion exists to require the employee to undergo a controlled substances test must be based on specific contemporaneous articulable observations concerning the appearance behavior speech or body odors of the employee the observations may include indications of the chronic and withdrawal effects of controlled substances a written record shall be made of the observations leading to a controlled substance reasonable suspicion test and signed by the supervisor who made the observations within twentyfour 24 hours of the observed behavior or before the results of the controlled substances test are released whichever is earlier all city employees shall be required to submit to a controlled substance test where there is reasonable suspicion to believe that the employee has used or is using a controlled substance prior to reporting for duty or while on duty or prior to or while attending any city function on or off city property 12 trained observers for reasonable suspicion tests of any city employee authorized by this policy the required observations for alcohol andor controlled substances reasonable suspicion testing shall be made by a trained supervisor the person who makes the determination that reasonable suspicion exists to conduct an alcohol test shall not conduct the alcohol test of the employee persons designed to determine whether reasonable suspicion exists to require an employee to undergo testing shall receive at least sixty 60 minutes of training on alcohol misuse and receive at least an additional sixty 60 minutes of training on controlled substances use the training shall cover the physical behavioral speech and performance indicators of probable alcohol misuse and use of controlled substances 13 returntoduty in the event that an employee is allowed to return to duty before an employee returns to duty after engaging in conduct prohibited by this policy concerning alcohol the employee shall undergo a returntoduty alcohol test with a negative result in the event an employee is allowed to return before an employee returns to duty after engaging in conduct prohibited by this policy concerning controlled substances the employee shall undergo a returntoduty controlled substances test with a result indicating a verified negative result for controlled substances use 14 followup in the event an employee who has engaged in conduct prohibited in this policy or any other city policy regarding alcohol and controlled substances is allowed to return to work and in the event a determination is made that an employee is in need of assistance in resolving problems associated with alcohol misuse andor use of controlled substances the city shall ensure that the employee is subject to unannounced followup alcohol andor controlled substances testing as directed by a substance abuse professional followup alcohol testing shall be conducted only when the employee is performing job functions just before the employee is to perform job functions or just after the employee has ceased performing job functions 15 prohibitions alcohol if any city employee tests positive for alcohol no employee shall report for duty or remain on duty after having tested positively the employee may be subject to termination no city employee shall be on duty or operate a motor vehicle while the employee possesses alcohol if the city has actual knowledge that the employee possesses alcohol the employee shall not be permitted to drive or continue to drive a commercial motor vehicle the city employee may be subject to termination no employee shall use alcohol while performing job functions if the city has actual knowledge that an employee is using alcohol while performing job functions the employee shall not be permitted to perform or continue to perform job functions no city employee shall report for duty while under the influence of alcohol nor shall they consume alcohol while on duty or while attending a cityrelated function the employee shall be removed from hisher regularly assigned duties until an employment decision is made the employee or other employee may be subject to termination no employee required to take a postaccident alcohol test shall use alcohol for eight 8 hours following the accident or until he or she undergoes a postaccident alcohol test whichever occurs first 16 prohibitions controlled substances no city employee shall report for duty or remain on duty when the employee uses any controlled substance except when the use is pursuant to the instructions of a physician who has advised an employee that the substance does not adversely affect the employees ability to safely operate a commercial motor vehicle or with regard to any other employee when the employee has been advised that the substance does not adversely affect the employees performance of regularly assigned duties the city may require an employee to inform the employer of any therapeutic drug use no city employee shall report for duty or remain on duty if the employee tests positive for controlled substances if the city has actual knowledge that an employee has tested positive for controlled substances the employee shall not be permitted to drive or continue to drive a commercial motor vehicle or to perform or continue to perform safetysensitive functions  or in the case of any other city employee the employee shall be removed from hisher regularly assigned duties until an employment decision is made the employee may be subject to termination 17 consequences with regard to commercial motor vehicle operators consequences required by federal law for violating this policy include the following a removal from job functions 1 no employee shall perform job functions including driving a motor vehicle or operating equipment if the employee has engaged in conduct prohibited by this or other city policies regarding use of alcohol or controlled substances 2 the city shall not permit any employee to perform safetysensitive functions including driving a commercial motor vehicle if the city has determined that the employee has violated this policy 3 in cases where an employee is also employed in a nondriving capacity by the city disciplinary action imposed for violation of alcohol and controlled substances policies shall apply to the employee functions only however upon recommendation of the employees supervisor disciplinary measures up to and including termination of employment with the city may be considered for nondriving functions b required evaluation and testing no employee who has engaged in conduct prohibited by this policy shall be permitted to perform any job functions including driving a commercial motor vehicle unless the employee has been referred for evaluation and treatment 18 other alcoholrelated coverage no employee tested under the provisions of this policy who is found to test positive for alcohol shall perform or continue to perform job functions for the city including driving a motor vehicle or operate equipment nor shall the city permit the employee to perform or continue to perform job functions until the start of the employees next regularly scheduled duty period but not less than twentyfour 24 hours following administration of the test except as provided above the city may not take any action under this policy against an employee based solely on a positive test showing an alcohol concentration less than 004 this provision does not prohibit the city from taking any action otherwise consistent with law based on its own authority 19 other penalties except as expressly provided in this policy nothing in the federal regulations shall be construed to affect the authority of the city with respect to the use or possession of alcohol or the use of controlled substances including authority and rights with respect to testing rehabilitation and other penalties 20 referral evaluation and treatment each employee who has engaged in conduct prohibited by this policy shall be advised by the city of the resources available to the employee in evaluating and resolving problems associated with the misuse of alcohol and use of controlled substances including the names addresses and telephone numbers of substance abuse professionals and counseling and treatments programs each employee who engages in conduct prohibited by this policy shall be evaluated by a substance abuse professional who shall determine what assistance if any the employee needs in resolving problems associated with alcohol misuse and controlled substances abuse in the event that an employee is permitted to return to work before the employee returns to duty requiring the performance of the safetysensitive function after engaging in conduct prohibited by this policy the employee shall undergo a returntoduty alcohol test with a negative result if the conduct involved alcohol or a controlled substance test with a verified negative result if the conduct involved a controlled substance in addition if the employee is allowed to return to work and if heshe is identified as needing assistance in resolving problems associated with alcohol misuse or controlled substance abuse a heshe shall be evaluated by a substance abuse professional to determine that the employee has properly followed any rehabilitation program prescribed by the substance abuse professional  and b heshe shall be subject to unannounced followup alcohol and controlled substances tests administered by the city following the employees return to duty with regard to all other city employees who violate the citys policies on alcohol and controlled substances consequences include disciplinary action up to and including termination with regard to all applicants who violate the citys policies on alcohol and controlled substances consequences include rejection of application or withdrawal of employment offer 21 records the city shall maintain records of its alcohol misuse and controlled substances use prevention programs as provided in 49 cfr section  the records shall be maintained in a secure location with controlled access 22 reports the city shall prepare and maintain an annual calendar year summary of the results of its alcohol and controlled substances testing programs performed under this policy by march 15 of each year the city shall complete the annual summary covering the previous calendar year 23 policy requirements the city shall provide educational materials that explain the federal requirements and the citys policies and procedures with respect to meeting these requirements and shall ensure that a copy of these materials is distributed to each employee prior to the start of alcohol and controlled substances testing under this policy and to each employee subsequently hired or transferred into a position that requires driving a motor vehicle written notice to representatives of employee organizations of the availability of this information shall also be provided the materials to be made available to employees shall include detailed discussion of at least the following a the identity of the person designated by the city to answer employee questions about the materials b the categories of employees who are subject to the provisions of this policy c sufficient information about the safetysensitive functions performed by those employees to make clear what period of the workday the employee is required to be in compliance with this policy d specific information concerning employee conduct that is prohibited by this policy e the circumstances under which an employee will be tested for alcohol andor controlled substances under this policy f the procedures that will be used to test for presence of alcohol and controlled substances protect the employee and the integrity of the testing process safeguard the validity of the test results and ensure that those results are attributed to the correct employee g the requirement that an employee submit to alcohol and controlled substances tests administered in accordance with this policy h an explanation of what constitutes a refusal to submit to an alcohol or controlled substances test and the attendant consequences i the consequences for employees found to have violated this policy including the requirement that the employee be removed immediately from job functions and the procedures for referral evaluation and treatment j the consequences for employees found to have a positive alcohol test k information concerning the effects of alcohol and controlled substances use on an individuals health work and personal life  signs and symptoms of an alcohol or a controlled substances problem the employees or a coworkers  and available methods of intervening when an alcohol or a controlled substances problem is suspected including confrontation referral to any employee assistance program andor referral to management 24 reasonable suspicion testing all city employees are subject to drugalcohol testing if there is reasonable suspicion to believe that an employee has violated the citys policy concerning prohibition against the use of alcohol or controlled substances 25 restrictions employees testing positive for the use of a controlled substance dangerous drug or other drug or alcohol on a drug or alcohol test based on reasonable suspicion or on required alcohol and substance test may be subject to termination any person testing positive for the use of a controlled substance dangerous drug or other drug or alcohol on a required preemployment or annual drug or alcohol test shall not be hired be heard is protected roberts rules of order shall prevail at all meetings of the city council to the extent that roberts rules of order does not conflict with the texas open meetings act state statute or this ordinance unless otherwise prescribed by law council action on all motions shall be decided by a simple majority vote of the council all of the chairmans decisions regarding procedures including the chairmans refusal to allow a motion to be considered are subject to appeal by any member of the council a simple majority vote is all that is required to overrule the chairman on procedural issues if the chairman refuses to honor the appeal the person making the appeal may state the question and put the question to a vote  41994 minutes a the city secretary shall attend each abstract of his statements on any subject pertaining to city business and affairs in the minutes c the city secretary with consent of the council may enter in the minutes a synopsis of the discussion on any question coming regularly before the council  41994 presentation to the city council a request by resident any resident who wishes to address the council on any matter on the council agenda may do so by signing a list provided at any time prior to opening of the meeting and specifying the particular subject matter of such address if the subject matter listed by the resident who wishes to speak refers to an agenda item that has been placed on the agenda for the particular council session the resident will be allowed to speak prior to any council action on that agenda item b request by nonresident any nonresident wishing to address the council shall notify the secretary and specify his interest in the matter being considered twentyfour 24 hours prior to the time the meeting is being held upon timely notification a nonresident shall be permitted to address the council when the applicant claims an interest in a matter on the councils agenda and he is so situated that the disposition of the agenda may as a practical matter impair or impede his ability to protect that interest c reading of protests etc upon complying with the provisions of this section interested persons may at their discretion address the council by reading of protests petitions or communications in regard to matters under the councils consideration d written communication all interested parties or their authorized representatives may address the council by written communication regarding matters under the councils consideration e recognition no person shall address the council without first being recognized by the presiding officer or a majority of members of the council in attendance f procedure each person upon being properly recognized shall address the council microphone provided for the use of the public and give his name and address in an audible tone of voice for the records state the subject he wishes to discuss state whom he is representing if he represents an organization or other persons and unless further time is granted by majority vote of the council shall limit his remarks as follows when speaking on agenda items limit to five 5 minutes or if speaking on nonagenda items to ten 10 minutes all remarks shall be addressed to the council as a whole and not to any member thereof members of council may enter into discussion with or question the person addressing council g spokesperson for group in order to expedite matters and to avoid repetitious presentations whenever any group of persons wishes to address the council on the same subject matter it shall be proper for the presiding officer to request that a spokesperson be chosen by the group to address the council and in case additional matters are to be presented by any other member of said group to limit the number of such persons addressing the council  41994 rules of decorum a members of the governing body while the council is in session all members of the governing body must preserve and maintain order and decorum 1 subject matter every member desiring to speak shall confine discussion to the question under debate avoiding all personalities and indecorous language 2 interruptions a member of the city council shall not be interrupted while speaking 3 no member of the governing body shall speak during the citizens hearing except as herein permitted and all members shall refrain from making expressly impertinent slanderous discourteous or profane remarks and shall not willfully utter loud threatening or abusive language nor engage in any disorderly conduct which would impede disrupt or disturb the orderly conduct of any meeting hearing or other proceedings 4 no member of the governing body shall violate any portion of section 287 as amended including but not limited to subsection a1 styled subject matter which says  every member desiring to speak shall confine discussion to the question under debate avoiding all personalities and indecorous language this quoted portion of subsection a1 is interpreted to apply to all other portions of the agenda when the public is restricted from speaking b persons addressing council any resident may address council during the citizens hearing portions of any agenda addressing council means that comments shall be directed to council not questions asked of council those who are permitted to address council do not include members of the governing body this is for citizens as distinguished from council members because council members are not restricted to one part of the agenda and they have adequate time to speak during the rest of the meeting when the public is not allowed to speak the public only has these two 2 agenda positions to make their desires known to council the citizens hearing for agenda items to be limited to five 5 minutes from the time he or she commences talking the citizens hearing for nonagenda items to be limited to three 3 minutes from the time he or she commences talking no council member shall be permitted to speak or interrupt during the citizens hearing portion of the agenda without the consent of a majority of council unless an express exception applies and his or her attempt to speak during the citizens hearing shall be out of order these are the exceptions 1 the mayor may speak on parliamentary procedure and shall speak to preserve order during the citizens hearing portion of the agenda the mayor shall confine his or her comments to the ceremonial aspects of his or her role and to matters pertaining to how the meeting shall proceed on any item other than a discussion of procedure or reasonable and valid point of order he or she shall not permit a council member to speak without the approval of a majority of council 2 a council person may speak to exercise his or her right to remove a disorderly member of the audience allowed herein and to raise points of parliamentary procedure on a valid point of order 3 a council person may speak about removal of violators of decorum rules and during and about parliamentary matters dealing with rulings or actions by the presiding officer but not otherwise any member of the public making expressly impertinent slanderous discourteous or profane remarks or who willfully utters loud threatening or abusive language or who engages in any disorderly conduct which would impede disrupt or disturb the orderly conduct of any meeting hearing or other proceedings shall be called to order by any member of the governing body and if such conduct continues may at the discretion of any member of the governing body be removed and barred from further audience before the council during the meeting such removal power shall not be exercised to eject from the meeting a voting member of council or any officer employee or consultant for the city scheduled to assist council as part of his or her job in meetings to make a presentation or give testimony about a particular agenda item on the agenda when that agenda item is under deliberation at the meeting at which he or she is in attendance physical intimidation taunts threats or similar menacing conduct shall not be tolerated from a member of the audience or from a member of the governing body if a mayor or member of council persists in such unacceptable behavior he or she may be publicly censured by council and council may pursue other remedies until such conduct ceases or that person is no longer a member of council the remedy for boorish andor menacing behavior in a public official shall be reprimand censure impeachment or removal from office but not removal from a meeting at which he or she has a right to vote unless he or she commits a breach of the peace or a violation of the texas penal other words this section shall not be used to remove such an official but there are limits to such conduct that may justify removal c members of the audience no person in the audience shall engage in disorderly conduct such as hand clapping stamping of feet whistling use of profane or vulgar language yelling holding placards and similar demonstrations which conduct disturbs the peace and good order of the meeting d persons authorized to be within certain area no person except members of the council and the city staff shall be permitted past the speakers stand without the consent of the presiding officer or a majority vote of council members in attendance e no member of the public shall violate any portion of section 287 of the south houston as amended f it shall be unlawful to violate any provision of this section and the penalties shall be those provided for ordinance violation in the city g the provisions of this section are severable if any portion is declared to be unenforceable the remaining portions shall be enforceable  41994   72297   8597 lighting for cameras and recording devices supplemental lighting for television and motion picture cameras shall be used actions associated with a record before it is eligible for destruction 2 112190 municipal records declared public property all municipality records as defined in section 2101 are hereby declared to be officerdesignation the city secretary and the successive holders of said office shall serve as records management officer for the city as provided by state law each successive holder of the office addition to other duties assigned in this article the records management officer shall 1 administer the records management program and provide assistance to department heads in it implementation  2 municipality office and department to ensure maximum availability of the records in order to reestablish operations quickly and with minimum disruption and expense  4 develop procedures to ensure the permanent preservation of the historically valuable records of the municipality  5 establish standards for filing and storage equipment and for recordkeeping supplies  6 study the feasibility of and establishment of records management committee  duties a records management committee consisting of the department heads records liaison officers is hereby established the committee shall 1 assist the records management officer in the development of policies and procedures governing the records management program  2 review the performance of the program on a regular basis and propose changes and improvements if needed  3 review and approve records control schedules submitted by the records management officer  4 give final approval to the destruction of records in accordance with approved records control schedules  and 5 actively support and promote the records management program throughout the city 6 112190 records management plan to be developed  approval of plan  authority of plan a the records management officer and the records management committee shall develop a records management plan for the city for submission of the municipality the plan must contain policies and procedures designed to reduce the costs and improve the efficiency of recordkeeping to adequately protect the essential records of the municipality that are of historical value the plan must be designed to enable the records management officer to carry out his or her duties prescribed by state law and this article effectively b once approved by the city the records management plan shall be binding on all offices departments divisions programs commissions bureaus boards committees or similar entities of the city and records shall be created maintained stored microfilmed or disposed of in accordance with the plan c state law relating to the duties other responsibilities or recordkeeping requirements of a department head do not exempt the department head or the records in the department heads care from the application of this article and the records management plan adopted under it and may not be used by the department head as a basis for refusal to participate in the records management program of the city 7 112190 duties and responsibilities of department heads in addition to other duties assigned in this article department heads shall 1 cooperate with the records management officer in carrying out the policies and procedures established in the city for the efficient and economical management of records and in carrying out the requirements of this article  2 adequately document the transaction of government business and the services programs and duties for which the department head and his or her staff are responsible  and 3 maintain the records in his or her care and carry out their preservation microfilming destruction or other disposition only in accordance with the policies and procedures of the records management program of the city and the texas dial alarm any alarm or device which automatically selects a telephone line connected to police headquarters and reproduces a prerecorded message to report a criminal intrusion or other alarm system or device or his employees agents or representatives specifically excepted are acts of god such as false alarms caused by hurricanes tornadoes earthquakes and the like holdup alarm any authority means the city of south houston animal control office with authority over the area where the dog is kept 2 dangerous dog means a dog that a makes an unprovoked attack on a domesticated animal or person by biting or mauling that causes serious bodily injury and occurs in a place other than an enclosure in which the dog was being kept and that was reasonably certain to prevent the dog from leaving the enclosure on its own  or b commits unprovoked acts in a place other than an enclosure in which the dog was being kept and that was reasonably certain to prevent the dog from leaving the enclosure on its own and those acts cause a person to reasonably believe that the dog will attack bite or maul and cause serious bodily injury to that person 3 dog means a domesticated animal that is a member of the canine family 4 serious bodily injury means an injury characterized by severe bite wounds or severe ripping and tearing of muscle that would cause a reasonably prudent person to seek treatment from a medical professional and would require hospitalization without regard to whether the person actually sought medical treatment 5 secure enclosure means a fenced area or structure that is a locked  b capable of preventing the entry of the general public including children  c capable of preventing the escape or release of a dog  d clearly marked as containing a dangerous dog  and e in conformance with the requirements for enclosures established by the local animal control authority 6 owner means a person who owns or has custody or control of the dog b requirements for the city which by loud frequent or habitual crowing or any other noise annoyance from such poultry or fowl shall disturb the peace and quiet of any person of ordinary sensitivities any such person who believes that there has been a violation of this section shall have the right to file a complaint against the owner or keeper of such poultry or fowl in the code enforcement office of the city  whereupon a hearing within a reasonable time thereafter shall be held and a determination made as to whether such loud frequent or habitual crowing or other noise annoyed the peace of such person  and if so the court may thereupon declare such fowl to be a nuisance and order the owners or keepers thereof to remove such fowl from the city limits the failure to obey the order of the municipal court under this section shall constitute a class c misdemeanor in addition to such remedy as provided in this section should there be a conviction for any other violation of this section the party vehicle dealers ch 23 article i  in general definitions for the purposes of this chapter the following definitions shall apply auto wrecker the term auto wrecker shall mean any automobile truck or other vehicle which is used for the purposes of towing carrying pushing or otherwise transporting any motor vehicle for whatever the reason may be the term auto wrecker shall not be construed to include a service car or other vehicle not equipped with mechanical devices for transporting wrecked vehicles and not used for such purpose such as service cars equipped with compressed air containers and tools for performing minor repairs not involving towage or transportation of vehicles this exception shall not authorize evasion of this chapter and if any vehicle although not equipped with devices primarily used for towing vehicles is actually used for such purposes of ropes chains or otherwise the same shall be considered an auto wrecker within the terms of this chapter no auto wrecker license shall be required for those franchised utility companies who own and operate their own auto wreckers for towing their own equipment emergency auto wrecker the term emergency auto wrecker shall mean an auto wrecker which is dispatched to the scene of an accident by the chief of police or his representative from the wrecker rotation list where a vehicle has collided with another vehicle or other object or has been wrecked or disabled in any manner for the purpose or expectation of towing removing or hauling away the wrecked vehicle or vehicles from the scene of the accident or to remove a vehicle authority of the police department person the term person shall include both singular and plural and shall mean and include any individual firm corporation association or partnership owner  use a the city council shall establish and maintain a list of emergency wrecker license holders which shall be known as the wrecker rotation list this list shall be certified by city council and kept current at all times b the wrecker rotation list shall contain the names in alphabetical order of all qualified license holders requesting to be on such list and such list shall include up to two 2 vehicles of each license holder c an emergency auto wrecker license holder is qualified to be on such list if 1 he maintains at least one 1 certified wrecker  2 he maintains twentyfourhour wrecker service and has no more than two 2 telephone numbers which numbers are answered twentyfour 24 hours a day seven 7 days a week the use of a telephone answering service shall be permitted provided that if such a service is used the failure of a permit holder to communicate with the police communications center or its authorized agent within five 5 minutes following a call requesting a dispatch of a certified wrecker confirming that the permit holder shall immediately dispatch a certified wrecker to the desired location will result in a forfeiture by that permit holder of that call d when the police officer investigating a collision determines that any vehicle involved in a collision is unable to safely proceed under its own power or when the police officer determines that the driver of any vehicle involved in a collision is physically unable to move the vehicle to a location where it will not create a traffic hazard such officer shall request the driver to designate the emergency auto wrecker permit holder which he desires to remove the vehicle 1 when the designation has been properly made the police officer shall communicate the name of the designated permit holder to the police communications center or the authorized agent of the designated permit holder 2 the police communications center or such authorized agent shall cause the designated permit holder to be called and directed to send to the scene of the collision a certified wrecker e if the owner of a vehicle involved in a collision is physically unable to designate the permit holder he desires to remove the vehicle or he fails or refuses to designate one or he has no preference then the police officer shall communicate that fact immediately to the police communications center or its authorized agent the police communications center or its authorized agent shall then call the permit holder next in line on the wrecker rotation list after the last permit holder so called and request the permit holder to tow the vehicle from the scene of the collision after the last permit holder on said list has been called the next such call shall go to the first permit holder on said list f if the permit holder after arrival at the scene determines in conjunction with the police officer in charge that assistance is needed then the police officer shall communicate that fact immediately to the police communications center or its authorized agent which shall proceed under subsection e of this section g failure of any permit holder selected under subsections d or e of this section to deliver a wrecker to the scene within twenty 20 minutes of notification without justification acceptable to the police communications center shall cause the permit holder to forfeit that call if selection of the permit holder occurred under subsection d of this section then the police communications center or its authorized agent shall proceed as it would under subsection e of this section so notifying the requesting police officer  11679   82812 dispatch of rotating wreckersthrough an authorized agent  fee in lieu of dispatching wrecker companies on the wrecker rotation list police communications or cause to be driven a wrecker to or near the scene of a collision on a street in this city unless such person has been called to the scene by the south houston police communications center or its authorized agent or by a party involved in the collision  provided that in an emergency when it appears necessary to prevent death or bodily injury to any person involved in a collision the prohibition of this section shall be inapplicable  11679 duties of emergency license holder in providing safe and prompt wrecker service a it shall be the obligation of all license holders under this article to operate wrecker businesses so as to provide safe and prompt removal of wrecked or disabled vehicles from the public streets of the city when properly called upon to do so in accordance with the provisions of this article b the duty to provide safe and prompt wrecker service upon call includes but is not limited to the following specific duties 1 upon receiving a call from the police communications center or its authorized agent the license holder shall in accordance with the provisions of this article dispatch the requested wrecker to the desired location or if the requested wrecker is not then available for service the permit holder shall immediately so inform the police communications center or its authorized agent 2 upon arriving at the scene of a collision within the incorporated limits of the city wrecker company personnel shall take directions from the police officer investigating that collision and shall obey all lawful orders given them by any police officer investigating such accident 3 wrecker company personnel of a permit holder which hauls any vehicle from the scene of a collision within the incorporated limits of the city shall remove the debris of the collision from the public streets this duty specifically includes removal of broken glass and metal fragments from the street and the removal of any load of any vehicle from the traveled portion of the street so as to eliminate any hazard to vehicular traffic this does not include the responsibility to unload cargo from the wrecked vehicle in order to permit hauling such debris should be disposed of in a manner which will keep it out of gutters storm sewers streams public rightsofway and property not belonging to the wrecker company without the consent of the property owner 4 any license holder on the wrecker rotation list must tow or have towed the damaged vehicle to a repair shop or to a place designated by the owner unless the owner of the vehicle is disabled by physical injury and is therefore unable to designate a location for the vehicle to be towed  the license holder may then store the vehicle in a depository as described in paragraph b6 of this section 5 no license holder shall store any vehicles or wreckers on the public streets or rightsofway license holders will use reasonable care in the storage of property not belonging to said permit holders so as to minimize the risk of theft or damage 6 all license holders on the wrecker rotation list shall maintain or have access to vehicle depositories located within 300 yards of the incorporated limits of the city the vehicle depository if an open lot shall be enclosed by a fence of adequate construction which is a minimum of six 6 feet in height which fence shall be kept wellsecured opaque so as the vehicle may not be observed from the street and lighted the vehicle depository may be in an enclosed building which shall be kept wellsecured failure to meet these conditions will subject a permit holder to administrative penalties as set out in this article the chief of police or his representative must approve of said storage area or lot 7 all license holders shall comply with all ordinances of the city failure to do so will subject a license holder to administrative penalties as set out in this article in addition to other civil remedies or penal provisions of the statutes or ordinances in question  11679   21886   emergency auto wrecker service owners records each owner of an emergency auto wrecker permit issued under this chapter shall keep full and complete books of accounts and article iv  nonconsent towing and repossessions companies report all nonconsent tows and repossessions to the city it shall be the requirement of all companies operating within the city of south houston conducting nonconsent tows and repossessions of vehicles within the city of south houston texas to report all nonconsent tows and repossessions to the city of south houston texas all repossessions shall be reported before and after the vehicle in question is repossessed the city of south houston texas shall maintain a record of all nonconsent tows and repossessions reported to the city of south houston texas all businesses that perform nonconsent tows and repossessions shall be required to be registered with and permitted by the city of south houston texas the city of south houston texas shall maintain the records of the nonconsent tows and repossessions in the interest of the safety of the citizens of the city of south houston texas  7913   10813 fees and fines each business that performs nonconsent tows will be required to pay the city of south houston texas the sum of fifty dollars $5000 per nonconsent tow each business that performs repossessions will be required to pay the city of south houston texas the sum of twentyfive dollars $2500 for each vehicle repossessed in the city limits of south houston failure to report a nonconsent tow will result in a class c misdemeanor with a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars $50000 failure to report a repossession before a motor vehicle is repossessed will result in a class c misdemeanor with a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars $50000 failure to report a repossession after a motor vehicle is repossessed will result in a class c misdemeanor with a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars $50000 failure to register with the city of south houston to perform nonconsent tows will result in a class c misdemeanor with a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars $50000 failure to obtain a permit with the city of south houston to perform nonconsent tows will result in a class c misdemeanor with a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars $50000 the nonconsent tow fee and the repossession fee must be paid on or before the first of each calendar month failure to pay said fees on or before the first of each calendar month will result in the revocation of the companys towing permit and all towing privileges within the territorial limits of the city of south houston harris county texas failure to pay the nonconsent tow fee will result in a class c misdemeanor with a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars $50000 failure to pay the repossession fee will result in a class c misdemeanor with a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars $50000  7913   10813   122314 authorized and registered editors note  adopted  did not specifically amend the such ordinance was treated as adding a new section 68 at the editors discretion carports a generallycarport defined a carport is defined as an opensided structure which may or may not be attached to an existing structure on one end and supported by poles or decorative posts a carport is to be used only for temporary parking of motor vehicles trailers or boats no carport is allowed to substitute for a garage as defined or required by any existing ordinances a carport although considered a permanent structure cannot be used for any purpose other than motor vehicle or trailer or boat parking b setback requirements no carport shall be erected closer than five feet to the front property line when measured from the longest projection of the roof line eave or decorative overhang  except when there is a 20foot setback line the fivefoot requirement shall not apply in such case the carport shall not be extended closer than one foot from the property line c building requirements carports may be constructed of metal and wood only and may be attached to the main structure at the innermost end with either a flat roof or a roof with a pitch all wood carports soffit and wood posts must be covered with noncombustible material such as hardiplank brick or stucco the carport shall not have any ceiling openings accessible for any storage area the carport shall be supported at its outermost end by not more than two 2 metal or wood stanchions poles with braces anchored in a manner approved by the building official and such poles shall not be placed closer than five 5 feet on both sides of the property  except the front of the carport roofs edge shall not be placed closer than one 1 foot from the property line the horizontal portion of the carport framework shall not be less than eight 8 feet nor more than twelve 12 feet above grade natural ground elevation the stanchions supporting the carport shall be separated by not more than twenty 20 feet and the roof overhang shall not exceed two 2 feet from the supporting stanchions on any side no wall shall be erected or attached to any carport permitted under this section  41905   12009   1 dangerous buildings defined for the purposes of this article all buildings or structures which have any or all of the following defects shall be deemed dangerous buildings  1 those whose interior walls or other vertical structural members list lean or buckle to such an extent that a plumb line passing center of gravity falls outside of the middle third of its base 2 those which exclusive of the foundation show thirtythree 33 percent or more of damage or deterioration of the supporting member or members or fifty 50 percent of damage or deterioration of the nonsupporting enclosing or outside walls or covering 3 those which have improperly distributed loads upon the floors or roofs or in which the same are overloaded or which have insufficient strength to be reasonably safe for the purpose used 4 those which have been damaged by fire wind or other causes so as to have become dangerous to life safety morals or the general health and welfare of the occupants or the people of the city 5 those which are so dilapidated decayed unsafe unsanitary or which so utterly fail to provide the amenities essential to decent living that they are unfit for human habitation or are likely to cause sickness or disease so as to work injury to the health morals safety or general welfare of those occupying such building 6 those having light air and sanitation facilities which are inadequate to protect the health morals safety or general welfare of human beings who live or may live therein 7 those which have inadequate facilities for egress in case of fire or panic or having insufficient stairways elevators fire escapes or other means of communication 8 those which have parts thereof which are so attached that they may fall and injure members of the public or property 9 those which because of their condition are unsafe unsanitary or dangerous to the health morals safety or general welfare of the people of this city 10 those existing in violation of any provisions of this article the building code or other ordinances of the city a 4577 declaration of nuisance all dangerous buildings are hereby declared to be public nuisances and shall be repaired vacated and repaired or vacated and demolished as provided for in this article c 4577 creation composition etc of building committee for the purpose of carrying out the provisions of this article there is hereby created a building committee composed of five 5 members three 3 of whom shall constitute a quorum the building committee shall be appointed by the mayor and in the event of the absence or unavailability of a member of such committee or should the office of any member become vacant the mayor may complete the committee by appointment of a new member or members e 4577 standards to be followed in issuing orders under article the following standards shall be followed in substance by the building inspector or city fire marshal or city health officer and the building committee in ordering repair or vacation or demolition of a dangerous building under this article 1 if the dangerous building can reasonably be repaired so that it will no longer exist in violation of the terms of this article it shall be ordered repaired 2 if the dangerous building is in such condition as to make it dangerous to the health morals safety or general welfare of its occupants it shall be ordered to be vacated 3 in any case where a dangerous building is fifty 50 percent damaged decayed or deteriorated it shall be repaired or demolished 4 in all cases where a dangerous building cannot be repaired so that it will no longer exist in violation of the provisions of this article it shall be demolished 5 in all cases where a dangerous building is a fire hazard existing or erected in violation of the terms of this article the building code or any other ordinance of the city or any other requirement of law of the state it shall be repaired or demolished b 4577  a 102787 city officers and employees not
